y_shenhar wrote:
> 
> 
> Hello,
> 
> I am writing a java library that needs to make native calls.
> I would appreciate ideas on how to unit test the Java code (assuming
> that the native code works).

If you know how the native code is supposed to behave, then place that 
behavior behind an interface. Now you want to test the clients of that 
interface.

In production code, give your clients the real implementation of that 
interface, that actually talks to the native code.

In tests, give your clients a "fake" implementation that simulates the 
native code. Write a test for each different kind of response the 
interface can give your clients to see how your clients respond.

Also in tests, give your clients a "mock" implementation that verifies 
how clients use the native code: do they invoke the right methods with 
the right parameters, and so on.

For more information on "mock" and "fake" (fakes are also called stubs), 
search the web and read _JUnit Recipes_, _Test Driven Development: A 
Practical Guide_, _JUnit in Action_ and other fine books and articles.
